title: 106_s1704
content: The "Access to High Standards Act" is the short title of this legislation. The "Access to High Standards Act" aims to address the lack of academic preparation in secondary schools, leading to limited employment opportunities and high college dropout rates. It emphasizes the importance of raising academic standards and modeling them after advanced placement programs, which are endorsed by many education leaders and half of all States. (4) Advanced placement programs offer 30 college-level courses, reaching 60% of secondary schools and over 1,000,000 students, with test scores accepted for college credit at 3,000+ colleges worldwide. (5) 24 States fund programs to increase participation in advanced placement, including teacher professional development and test fee coverage. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement courses by highlighting the success of State programs that cover test fees and grant academic credit for high scores. These programs have raised academic standards, increased enrollment, achievement, and minority participation in advanced placement programs. The Act aims to encourage more students to take advanced placement exams by highlighting the benefits of the program, such as improved SAT scores and academic achievements. It also supports State and local efforts to raise academic standards through advanced placement programs. The Act aims to increase student participation and success in advanced placement programs by broadening availability, diversifying student participation, providing greater access for low-income students, and demonstrating that larger and more diverse groups of students can succeed in these programs. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for disadvantaged students and increase participation rates to 25% of the student population. The Act aims to increase access to advanced placement courses for disadvantaged students and increase participation rates to 25% of the student population. SEC. 3. ADVANCED PLACEMENT PROGRAM GRANTS. The Secretary will award grants to eligible entities for a 3-year period to carry out authorized activities. Eligible entities are defined as State or local educational agencies. Priority will be given to eligible entities submitting grant applications. Priority will be given to eligible entities demonstrating a need for advanced placement programs, involvement of business and community organizations, availability of matching funds, focus on English, mathematics, and science programs, and targeting specific programs in the State. An eligible entity, either a State educational agency or a local educational agency, can use grant funds to target schools with a high concentration of low-income students. Grant funds can also be used to expand access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals through teacher training, course development, and curriculum coordination. The eligible entity can use grant funds for teacher training, pre-advanced placement course development, curriculum coordination, books, supplies, and other activities related to expanding access to advanced placement programs for low-income individuals. The entity must submit an application to the Secretary for the grant, and report data annually on the number of students taking advanced placement courses. The eligible entity receiving a grant must report annually to the Secretary on the number of students taking advanced placement courses, the number of tests taken, test scores, and demographic information. The Secretary will compile this information and report to Congress. Authorization of appropriations is provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the eligible entity receiving a grant to report annually to the Secretary on advanced placement course data, with $25,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2000 and additional funding for the following years. The Secretary will compile and report this information to Congress. SEC. 4. ON-LINE ADVANCED PLACEMENT COURSES. The Secretary will award grants to local educational agencies to provide students with online advanced placement courses. Agencies can contract with organizations for course provision and support services. Priority is given to agencies serving low-income or rural students without access to such courses. Grant funds can be used for various purposes. Grant funds under this section can be used to purchase online curriculum, train teachers, or buy course materials. Local educational agencies must submit applications for grants, and $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2000 with additional funding for the following years. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PRIORITIES FOR ADVANCED PLACEMENT. Each institution of higher education receiving Federal funds must distribute information to secondary school counselors or advanced placement coordinators regarding academic credit for advanced placement test scores. They must also standardize the form and manner of disseminating this information within 4 years. Additionally, there are initiatives for Javits gifted and talented students at the state and local levels. State and local initiatives focus on programs for gifted and talented students that incorporate advanced placement courses and tests. The Education Act of 1965 is amended to prioritize grants for Upward Bound projects focusing on increasing student participation in advanced placement courses. The Act defines terms like "advanced placement incentive program" as providing activities to low-income individuals, "advanced placement test" as administered by the College Board, and "high concentration of low-income students" as serving a student population with 40% or more from families below the poverty level. The curr_chunk discusses the definitions of "low-income individual" and "institution of higher education" in relation to grants for Upward Bound projects. It specifies the criteria for a low-income individual to take an advanced placement test and defines an institution of higher education. The curr_chunk provides definitions for terms such as "local educational agency", "secondary school", and "State educational agency" as well as clarifying the meaning of "Secretary" and "State" in the context of education legislation.
